Package me.wobblyyyy.edt

Interface Mappable<K,​V>

  • Type Parameters:
    K - the type of key element in the map.
    V - the type of value element in the map.
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    DynamicMap, FrozenMap, IntegerMap, StaticMap, StringMap
    public interface Mappable<K,​V>
    Interface shared between all map implementations, such as the (sexy) DynamicMap and the (equally sexy) StaticMap.

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • put

        void put​(K key,
         V value)
        Put a given pair into the map. If the map already contains an element with the same key as the key that was inputted, replace that key's value. If the map doesn't contain the given key and the map can be expanded to include it, insert the value into the map.
        Parameters:
        key - the key that the value should go under.
        value - the value the key should have.
        See Also:
        put(KeyValue)

      • put

        void put​(KeyValue<K,​V> keyValuePair)
        Put a given pair into the map. If the map already contains an element with the same key as the key that was inputted, replace that key's value. If the map doesn't contain the given key and the map can be expanded to include it, insert the value into the map.
        Parameters:
        keyValuePair - a pair of a key and a value that should be inserted into the map. This pair contains both a key and a value.
        See Also:
        put(Object, Object)

      • get

        V get​(K key)
        Get the value that a specified key in the map contains.
        Parameters:
        key - the key to query for.
        Returns:
        if the map contains the requested key, return the key's value. If the map doesn't contain the requested key, however, return null, indicating that the requested key could not be found.

      • getKey

        K getKey​(V value)
        Get the key associated with a specified value.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to search for.
        Returns:
        the first instance of a key that matches with the given value. If there are no instances of the value in the map, return null. If there are multiple instances of the requested key in the map, only return the key of the first of those indexes.

      • containsKey

        boolean containsKey​(K key)
        Check to see if the map contains a specified key.
        Parameters:
        key - the key to look for.
        Returns:
        true if the map contains the requested key. Return false if the map doesn't contain the requested key.

      • containsValue

        boolean containsValue​(V value)
        Check to see if the map contains a specified value.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to look for.
        Returns:
        true if the map contains at least one instance of the specified value, and false if it doesn't.

      • getKeys

        Arrayable<K> getKeys()
        Get an Arrayable element based on all of the keys contained in the map's data set.
        Returns:
        an Arrayable element composed of all of the map's keys.

      • getValues

        Arrayable<V> getValues()
        Get an Arrayable element based on all of the values contained in the map's data set.
        Returns:
        an Arrayable element composed of all of the map's values.

      • size

        int size()
        Get the size of the map.

        This attribute is based on the quantity of entries contained in the map. Lone keys and lone values (if those exist) are not counted towards the total size of the map. In the case of map implementations that use dynamic arrays, size should still represent the total ACTIVE size, not the total allocated size.

        Returns:
        the map's size.

      • clear

        void clear()
        Clear all of the values from a map.

        Clearing a map will not reset the entire map to a new map. Rather, it will clear each of the values from the map. Each of the key elements should remain entirely intact. The value data structure should not be de-allocated - rather, it should remain allocated and ready to receive new information.

        If you're interested in "starting fresh," so to speak, you can create a new instance of the map you're using. Otherwise, this lovely clear method should get the job done fairly well.

      • itr

        ItrPair<K,​V> itr()
        Get the map's iterator.
        Returns:
        the map's iterator. The specific implementation of the iterator is left entirely up to the implementing class, but each iterator is an implementation of the ItrPair interface, so they function near identically in practice.
